Steps for Regrowing Vegetables from Scraps

Do you often find yourself throwing away vegetable scraps, such as the bottoms of lettuce heads or the ends of celery stalks? Did you know that these scraps can actually be regrown into new vegetables? Not only is this a great way to reduce food waste, but it can also save you money on groceries. Here are some simple steps for regrowing vegetables from scraps:

Lettuce and Cabbage

To regrow lettuce or cabbage, simply cut off the bottom inch of the head and place it in a bowl with about half an inch of water. Place the bowl in a sunny spot and change the water every couple of days. After about a week, you should start to see new leaves sprouting from the center of the plant. Once these leaves are a few inches tall, you can transplant them into soil.

Celery

To regrow celery, cut off the bottom two inches of the stalk and place it in a shallow dish with enough water to cover about half an inch of the bottom. Place the dish in a sunny spot and change out the water every couple of days. After about a week, small leaves will begin to emerge from inside the base. Once these leaves are at least three inches long, you can transplant them into soil.

Carrots

To regrow carrots, take leftover carrot tops (the greens) and place them in a shallow dish with water. Change out their water every day until they grow roots which should take around 4-5 days then transfer them over to soil.

Scallions

To regrow scallions (also known as green onions), simply save their white bulbs after chopping up their green stems. Place the bulbs in a glass filled with water so that the roots are submerged, and change out their water every couple of days. You should see new green shoots emerging from the top within a week or two.

Bok Choy

Bok choy is also an easy vegetable to regrow. Simply cut off the bottom inch of the head and place it in a shallow dish with enough water to cover about half an inch of the bottom. Keep changing their water every 1-2 days until you see new leaves sprouting up then transfer them over to soil.

Regrowing vegetables from scraps is not only fun but also helps reduce food waste while allowing you to enjoy fresh produce at home without spending money on buying new seeds or plants. So next time you’re cooking and have some leftover vegetable scraps, give these steps a try!

Plan Now, Harvest Later – Steps to Prep Soil for Spring Plantings

Spring is the perfect time to start a garden. Whether you’re planting vegetables or flowers, there’s nothing quite as satisfying as watching your plants grow and thrive. But before you can start planting, you need to prepare your soil. Here are some steps you can take to get your soil ready for spring plantings.

Step 1: Clear the Area

The first step in preparing your soil is to clear the area where you want to plant. Remove any weeds, rocks, or debris that may be in the way. This will create a clean slate for your new plants and give them plenty of room to grow.

Step 2: Test Your Soil

Testing your soil is an important step in determining what nutrients it needs. You can purchase a soil test kit from most garden centers or online retailers. Follow the instructions on the kit carefully and take note of the results.

Step 3: Add Compost

Compost is a great way to add nutrients back into your soil naturally. It also helps with water retention and drainage. You can purchase compost from most garden centers or create your own by composting kitchen scraps and yard waste.

Step 4: Till Your Soil

Tilling your soil helps loosen it up and makes it easier for roots to take hold. Use a tiller or hand tool to break up any clumps of dirt and mix in compost evenly throughout the area.

Step 5: Add Fertilizer

If your soil test indicates that you need additional nutrients, consider adding fertilizer appropriate for what you are growing at this stage. Be sure not over-fertilize, which can harm your plants. Follow the instructions on the packaging carefully.

Step 6: Water Your Soil

Before planting, water your soil thoroughly to ensure that it is moist and ready for new growth. Be sure not to over-water or leave standing water as this can cause root rot.

Conclusion

By following these steps before you plant in spring, you’ll be giving your garden a strong foundation for healthy growth throughout the season. With proper care and attention, you’ll be harvesting fresh produce or enjoying beautiful flowers in no time!
